FREDERICK COUNTY DIVISION OF UTILITIES & SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT
NEW DESIGN ROAD WATER TREATMENT FACILITY
FACILITY ID #1000 0002 4065

SECTION I 

The Frederick County Division of Utilities & Solid Waste Management (DUSWM) owns and operates several Water & Wastewater treatment plants in Frederick County Maryland.  This RMP is for facility 1000 0002 4065, the largest of the Water Treatment Plants (WTP) owned and operated by Frederick County Division of Utilities & Solid Waste Management.

This facility treats about three (3) mgd from the Potomac River and serves 18228 residential Customers (6751 residential accounts) and 491 commercial/industrial accounts.  Twenty-four thousand pounds of Chlorine is the maximum amount of chemical stored at this facility at any given time.  There are no other hazardous chemicals used or stored at or above reportable quantities at this facility.  There has never been a release of Chlorine at this facility that has escaped off-site.  This is one of two (2) Division facilities required to submit RMP data; therefore, much of the data contained in this report is similar or the same for both facilities.

On a routine basis Frederick County¿s insurance carriers make site inspections of major Division facilities including the New Design Road WTP.  These inspections include review of policies, procedures, training programs, environmental permits, contingency plans, and Tier II inventories.  Frederick County has had two (2) RMP audits, one in 2002 and another in 2004.


SECTIONS II & III

Both release scenarios used in this report use a single ton container.  With policies and procedures in place as well as the safety record of this facility, it is believed that this is the largest amount of chlorine that would be released in a single incident.

The first scenario was a Chlorine gas release that takes place over a 10 minute period of time.  This time frame is the estimated time that it would take for sensors to activate and alarm, personnel to r

espond with appropriate PPE and equipment and begin a valve or line repair or seal the container.

The second scenario was a rupture of a fusible plug (relief valve) with the total contents of the container emptying in eight (8) minutes.  This time frame is based on the size of the fusible plug and the emptying of the entire container.


SECTION IV & V

Frederick County Division of Utilities & Solid Waste Management does not use or store flammable chemicals/materials subject to RMP requirements; therefore no other scenarios are submitted.


SECTION VI

The New Design Road WTP has an excellent safety record.  Having had no accidental releases in its history of now greater than 35 years, there is nothing to report.


SECTION VII & VIII

What-if & What-if/Checklists were used to update the PHA for this facility.  Review of the facility specific SOPs and Division policies and procedures are conducted annually.

Because of the critical nature of water supply, Frederick County DUSWM has built redundancy into many of its most critical processes.  This redundancy includes dual power and generators for power failures, duplicate pumps, controls, and sensors for other equipment.  Audible and visual alarms and procedures are in place for routine and emergency process control.  Automatic controls and shutoffs are equipped with manual backups in the event of power failures or other emergencies that may cause equipment control failure.

This facility has a Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) at the main gate to the facility.  This gate is electrically operated with either card key access or manual operation in the facility¿s administration building when the call box is activated.  Chlorine containers are stored in a building which is separate from the administration and laboratory building.  The Chlorine building is not ventilated to the outside atmosphere and is equipped with a chlorine scrubber system.  Chlorine detectors are stationed at critical areas and connected to audible and

visual alarms.  This system is tested routinely in accordance with established protocols.

Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are continually reviewed and revised as necessary.   All policies and procedures are reviewed annually as well as for this RMP.  Frederick County DUSWM has an extensive Occupational Health & Safety Program.  This program has set the benchmark for many other safety committees/programs within other Frederick County Divisions and Departments.  Policies and plans are in place and training for all employees takes place throughout the year.  Currently theses plans/policies or training include the following:

PPE (Personal Protective Equipment)
Hazard Communication (RTK)
Emergency Action & Fire Prevention & Extinguisher Use
Chlorine Safety/Chlorine Repair Kit ¿A & B¿
Emergency Response to Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Releases
Bloodborne Pathogens, First Aid & CPR
Atmospheric Testing & Respiratory Protection
Confined Space Entry
Safe Lifting
Fork Lift Safety
Defensive Driving

Review of all policies is ongoing throughout the year.  Formal reviews are conducted on an annual basis.  Formal reviews were conducted for this RMP Submission.  An on-the-job training (OJT) program has been implemented using both job performance checklists as well as health & safety training for performance evaluation.

Contractors hired to work on major projects must demonstrate that their personnel are competent to work in Confined Spaces, have Atmospheric Testing Equipment and knowledge, have appropriate Respiratory Protection and comply with other County and Division safety policies.

The DUSWM has an active Safety Committee.  This committee inspects DUSWM facilities on a periodic basis and also assists in policy review.

The DUSWM has implemented a Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) for tracking equipment, repairs (emergency as well as routine), preventative maintenance tasks, and resources (man-hours, parts, and equipment).


SECTION IX

The DUSWM is a Fr

ederick County agency that works closely with other County agencies to maintain its Emergency Response preparedness.  Other County and City agencies include Frederick County Department of Fire & Emergency Services (DFRS), Local Emergency Management Office, Frederick City, and other County Municipalities.  Currently the DUSWM is working with the Frederick County Office of Emergency Services to sponsor a seminar from George Washington University ¿Public Works: Preparing for the Responding to Weapons of Mass Destruction/Terrorism Incidents.¿  The Division¿s Emergency Response Plan includes notification, evacuation and accountability requirements as well as health & safety instructions that are to be used in the event of a release.  Each facility location is required to maintain site specific SOPs for facility shut down, evacuation, notification and accountability.  A rotational on-call supervisors list is included in the Division¿s ERP.  This on-call supervisors list includes home phone numbers, pager numbers and cell phone numbers.  Each on-call supervisor has a two-way radio for communications as well.  The Division¿s radios can also contact the Frederick County Emergency Communication Center (ECC).

Copies of any and all Policies, Plans, Procedures and maintenance records are available for review upon request.

CERTIFICATION 

To the best of my knowledge, information and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate and complete.
